title: Amazon asks FCC to extend satellite limit as it buys more SpaceX rides
description: The company needs to bring more of its satellites online so it can begin offering an internet-from-space service that was recently rebranded as Amazon Leo.

Key Points

- Amazon has asked the Federal Communications Commission for more time to meet a deadline that requires the company to deploy roughly 1,600 internet satellites by July 2026.
- The company needs to bring more of its satellites online so it can begin offering a paid service to customers. The company has earmarked at least $10 billion to build the network.
- Amazon booked more launches with Elon Musk's SpaceX and Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin as it seeks to speed up satellite deployments.

In this article

- [AMZN](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AMZN)

A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket is on the launch pad carrying Amazon's Project Kuiper internet network satellites, which are expected to eventually rival Elon Musk's Starlink system, at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Cape Canaveral, Florida, on April 9, 2025.

Steve Nesius \| Reuters

[Amazon](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AMZN/) has asked the Federal Communications Commission for more time to meet a deadline that requires the company to deploy roughly 1,600 internet satellites by July 2026.
